identificationModule.briefTitle: Sphenopalatine Ganglion Block for the Treatment of Post-Stroke Headache
identificationModule.officialTitle: Sphenopalatine Ganglion Block for the Treatment of Post-Stroke Headache

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Determine the effects of sphenopalatine ganglion (SPG) block in post-stroke headache.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The purpose of this study is to determine if sphenopalatine ganglion (SPG) block is a safe and effective treatment for acute post-stroke headache. Current literature lacks randomized controlled studies regarding the efficacy of different treatment modalities for acute post-stroke headache; additionally, there are no evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of acute post-stroke headache. Sphenopalatine ganglion block is a non-invasive procedure where an anesthetic agent is injected into the nares, reaching the SPG to relieve pain and autonomic features. This treatment has been effective in a variety of headache types but to our knowledge has not been studied in acute post-stroke headache.

armGroups.label: Liquid Lidocaine
armGroups.description: The investigational treatment is 1.5 mL of aqueous 2% lidocaine.

armGroups.label: Sham Placebo
armGroups.description: The placebo arm is 1.5mL of aqueous of saline.

interventions.name: Liquid Lidocaine
interventions.description: The investigational treatment is 2 mL of aqueous 2% lidocaine.

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: The active placebo comparator will be provided to participant.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Number of Migraine Headaches During Treatment Phase
primaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate the efficacy of Lidocaine delivered to SPG, based on the use of rescue medication and number of headache in headache diary

secondaryOutcomes.description: The quantitative scale ranges from 0 to 10, with 0 meaning "no headache at all" and 10 meaning "the worst possible headache."
Bitter taste, nose bleeding, throat discomfort

contacts.name: Adam H de Havenon, MD, MSCI
